section.p: The traditional method of dealing with young people who brake the law has been to send them to prison. However, in many countries the juvenile crime rate has continued to rise and goverments have had to look for other ways to tackle the problem, such as sentencing young offenders to community service. In common with all forms of punishment, this has both advantages and disadvantages.

Community service has a number of benefits. First of all, offenders devote their time and energy to giving something back to the community that has sufferred as a result of their criminal acts. Conseqently, they make amends in the most possitive way possible by helping those most afected. Secondly, they gain a sense of pride from the work they do and they also aquire usefull skills, which raises their self-esteem. Finaly, by working for and in the local community, they not only become more involved in it, but also develop feelings of responsability towards their fellow citizens, and can begin to biuld relationships based on respect. This, in turn, reduces the likelyhood of their re-offending.

However, community service also has some drawbacks. Firstly, it may be regarded as a 'soft' option by some offenders and, as a result, it will not act as an effective deterrant to crime. Furthermore, althougth community service is apropriate for many young offenders, it is not siutable for all of them. Some are too dangerous to be allowed to move around freelly in the community and need to be inprisoned, both for their own safety and for that of others. Lastly, it may be difficult to implement community service satisfactorily. Wheras in prison convicts are consentrated in a small area where they can be supervised by a small staff, offenders sentenced to community service are dispersed over a wide area and providing adequate supervision may proove both costly and impractical.

In conclusion, I beleive that community service is an effective form of punishment for young offenders who have commited only minor offences. For those who repeatedly break the law or commit more serious crimes, alternative methods of punishment may be necessary.
